Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: REU Site: Svalbard REU: Holocene and Modern Climate Change in the Norwegian High Arctic
Award.AbstractNarration: Since 2003, the PIs have been administering an REU site in the Svalbard archipelago for motivated geoscience undergraduate students, directly involving them in important climate change research and exposing them to the challenges and rewards of conducting high latitude research. Funds are provided to continue the Svalbard REU program for another year, based on the success of the program. Student research focuses on the climatic and surficial processes that operate in rapidly changing glacial, lacustrine, and fjord systems that may, in turn, archive the signature of anthropogenic changes in the high Arctic. Students define their research questions and design specific testable hypotheses throughout the program, complete their research projects at their home institutions during the following academic year and present their results at a professional conference. Most alumni of the program have gone into graduate programs better prepared for fundamental research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Svalbard REU (Research Experience for Undergraduates) marine program’s prime focus was on training undergraduate students, selected from applicants across the country, on how to conduct geoscientific research starting under extenuating field conditions of the high arctic, through to completion of a scientific report and presentation at a professional meeting. We also aimed to provide them with such an inspiring experience that they would follow a career in science. We did this by posing various scientific questions that address the understanding of tidewater glaciers ending in the fjords of Svalbard (79oN), Norway, during the summers of 2005, 2009, 2011 and 2014. Students worked on individual projects in close conjunction with faculty advisors and other student researchers. They formulated their own research questions with our guidance, developed their project, and completed their field research during a five-week field program. Scientifically, our studies were designed to collect data that address both ice dynamics and stability, as well as sedimentation processes, to assist interpreting records of past ice dynamics and in assessing modern oceanic/climatic changes. In addition to the undergraduates, we requested a middle or high school teacher (via the NSF PolarTrec program) to accompany us into the field and follow the students through their degrees. In that way we could spread the word about the excitement of scientific research via website blogs, Skype sessions, etc., with younger students who participated from across the country by following the teacher through the project.

We were very successful in our objectives with the students – 12 out of 14 have gone on for higher degrees in science and it is looking like 4 or 5 of the final 6 will do the same. Likewise, we were very successful with the teacher-younger student/parent interactions. Scientifically there have been 27 talks or posters presented at scientific meetings by the students and us. Additionally, we have three full scientific article publications thus far, and we anticipate more to come – not bad for undergraduates. We have collected some unique data that are otherwise unavailable in the scientific literature, thus providing added value to that of the research experience for undergraduate students.
